page.title: 06SMUGGLING IN THE W WIGHT
page.content: From early in the 17th century, smuggling has been a worthwhile occupation in the West Wight.The coastline is jagged with a reef of hidden rocks beneath the surface of the water around the Needles point.It is a well known fact that brandy was brought into and hidden in caves for later transportation by donkey along the muddy tracks to isolated farms in the West Wight.Here it was hidden until it was needed.As late as the 19th century,smuggling was still found and many of the descendants of these families still live here.It is a known fact that one of the very first lighthouse keepers, Mr Isaacs, was attacked by smugglers and thrown to his death over Scratchells Bay.The new lighthouse was rebuilt on the end of the rocks in 1858. Jane Elton 9 years
